column2: IPA: [ɐrˈtʲɵm]) is a city in Primorsky Krai
column4: located in the north of the Muravyov-Amursky Peninsula. Population: 102

column1: It was founded in 1924 near the Zybunny pit mine
column2: named after revolutionary Fyodor Sergeyev who was better known by his nickname Artyom. On October 26
column4: it was granted town status. In 2004
column5: the amalgamation of surrounding former urban-type settlements of Uglovoye
column7: and Artyomovsky into the city saw its official population rise from around 60

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column4: incorporated as Artyom City Under Krai Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: Artyom City Under Krai Jurisdiction is incorporated as Artyomovsky Urban Okrug.

column1: Half of the able-bodied population of Artyom is engaged in the production of materials.

column2: half of which are private. Among the consumer goods produced in the town are furniture
column4: sewing production. The companies employing the largest number of workers in Artyom are Primorskoye Mine Administration (3
column6: 100 people). Fifteen joint ventures have been registered in Artyom.

column1: Coal mining has always been the basis of the local economy
column2: although the existing coal reserves have practically been exhausted. The forecasts are that transport will be the most productive industry for Artyom's economic development.

column1: The Vladivostok International Airport is located near Artyom
column3: the Uglovoye military airfield. The largest Primorsky Krai railway junction is also found here. Annually

column5: and 24 million tons to Nakhodka. In 1994
